pageData.text: Microbiologists often need to evaluate the density of microbes in the environment. Several methods may be used to estimate microbial density. A <button class=glossary-text>standard plate count</button> relies on counting the number of colo-nies (discrete mounds of microbial cells) formed after the plate has been inoculated (seeded) with microbes which are then allowed to grow for a certain period of time. The number of colonies can be used to give an indication of the number of microbial cells in the original sample.

Population density can also be determined in a liquid culture by looking at the <button class=glossary-text>turbidity</button> (cloudiness) of the medium. In general, the greater the degree of turbidity, the greater the population density in the sample. The turbidity method is not as accurate as a standard plate count, but can be used to give a quick visual impression of the population density of a culture.

In this investigation, turbidity observations over time will be used to visualize changes in population density. A standard plate count will be used to determine the number of cells in an original sample.

Activity 2: Inoculation of Agar Plates from a Serial Dilution – 45 minutes

pageData.text: Dog feces contain up to three times the number of potential pathogens than human feces. Dog feces have been found to commonly contain protozoa cysts that include Giardia spp., Cryptosporidium spp., and Toxocara canis. Common bacterial pathogens found in dog feces include Campylobacter spp., Salmonella spp., Yersinia spp., and E. coli. There has also been increasing evidence that dog feces are a reservoir for antibiotic-resistant bacteria including vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE), enterococci with high-level aminoglycoside resistance (HLAR), and methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)1.

Stepping in dog poop isn’t just annoying, it can be dangerous. When it rains, dog waste is washed into rivers, lakes, and streams. Not only are the pathogens washed into the bodies of water, but dog feces also contain high amounts of nitrogen and phosphorus. These additional nutrients can throw off the balance of the aquatic habitat and can deplete the water of dissolved oxygen, which fish and other animals need to survive. Be sure to always clean up after your pet to prevent the spread of microbes and help protect aquatic environments.

1Cinquepalmi, V., Monno, R., Fumarola, L., Ventrella, G., Calia, C., Greco, M. F., Vito, D.d, & Soleo, L. (2012). Environmental contamination by dog’s feces: A public health problem?. International journal of environmental research and public health, 10(1), 72–84.
https://doi.org/10.3390/ijerph10010072

pageData.altText: A wooden dog with a sign that reads, No Trespooping We Shih Tzu Not.

pageData.text: Microbiologists often must determine the size of a microbial population. For example, in assessing water quality, the density of a particular type of microorganism may indicate the degree of a specific type of contamination, such as human or animal feces. There are two main approaches to determining the number of microbes in a sample.

The first approach is indirect. This may involve looking at the color of the culture or the cloudy haze, which is formed by small particles in solution, also known as <button class=glossary-text>turbidity</button>. Although indirect methods do not provide the exact number of microorganisms in the original sample, they do tend to be quicker and can be used to obtain a rough idea of relative population size. Indirect methods can be calibrated to give a more accurate result. In order to do this, an indirect method is compared with a direct method, using the same culture at the same time. After doing a count with a direct method, the turbidity measured may then be standardized for the total number of bacteria present in a culture.

A direct approach allows the exact number of microbes in a sample to be determined by simple observation and counting. This can be done by taking a known volume of a sample, looking at it under a microscope, and counting the microbes. Since the volume of the sample is known, the number of microbial cells counted can be directly translated to the total number present in the entire sample. This method can be time-consuming and tedious, but quite accurate in quantifying cell numbers. Most samples will contain some nonviable (dead, or unable to multiply) cells as well as viable (living, multiplying) cells. Thus, one limitation of direct microscopic counting is that living and dead cells may look alike. Furthermore, some microbes are motile (capable of movement), and unless steps are taken to halt their motion, it can be very difficult to count them. A similar direct technique uses an electronic particle counter, which is much faster than manual counting, and can be used for automatic, high throughput counting of large volumes of a sample. The main drawback to this technique is the high cost of a particle counter. The direct counting method used in this investigation is a , which requires neither a microscope nor a particle counter, and takes into account only viable microbial cells.

In a , the microbes are grown on an agar plate (agar in a Petri dish). Ideally, the individual cells will be spread so thinly and far apart that they do not touch adjacent cells. Over time, each individual cell will multiply and spread out, forming a discrete mound of cells called a . However, it is often the case that individual cells will cling tightly to one another, so that it is not practical to try to separate them. Therefore, instead of saying that each colony grows from a single cell, we say that a colony grows from a single , or .

pageData.question: Which method will you use to count microbial cells in this investigation?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The direct counting method used in this investigation is a standard plate count, which takes into account only viable microbial cells.

pageData.question: What is quantified in a standard plate count?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: A standard plate count quantifies the number of colony-forming units on an agar plate.

hintData.body: One limitation of direct microscopic counting is that living and dead cells may look alike. In addition, some microbes are capable of movement, and unless steps are taken to halt their motion, it can be very difficult to count them. A similar direct technique uses an electronic particle counter, which is much faster than manual counting, and can be used for automatic, high throughput counting of large volumes of a sample. The main drawback to this technique is the high cost of a particle counter. The direct counting method used in this investigation is a standard plate count, which requires neither a microscope nor a particle counter, and takes into account only viable microbial cells.<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>In a standard plate count, the microbes are grown on an agar plate (agar in a Petri dish). Ideally, the individual cells will be spread so thinly and far apart that they do not touch adjacent cells. Over time, each individual cell will multiply and spread out, forming a discrete mound of cells called a colony. With this method, it is said that a colony grows from a single colony-forming unit, or CFU.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: One limitation of direct microscopic counting is that living and dead cells may look alike. In addition, some microbes are capable of movement, and unless steps are taken to halt their motion, it can be very difficult to count them. A similar direct technique uses an electronic particle counter, which is much faster than manual counting, and can be used for automatic, high throughput counting of large volumes of a sample. The main drawback to this technique is the high cost of a particle counter. The direct counting method used in this investigation is a standard plate count, which requires neither a microscope nor a particle counter, and takes into account only viable microbial cells.<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>In a standard plate count, the microbes are grown on an agar plate (agar in a Petri dish). Ideally, the individual cells will be spread so thinly and far apart that they do not touch adjacent cells. Over time, each individual cell will multiply and spread out, forming a discrete mound of cells called a colony. With this method, it is said that a colony grows from a single colony-forming unit, or CFU.

pageData.text: Often, the population density in the original sample is so high that to add an undiluted sample directly to a plate would result in a plate which is overgrown with continuous or <button class=glossary-text>confluent</button> growth. Because it is impossible to count each individual <button class=glossary-text>colony</button> on a plate with confluent growth, it is therefore standard practice to perform a <button class=glossary-text>serial dilution</button> of the original sample.

In order to do this, 1 mL of the original sample is mixed with 9 mL of (either sterile water or an isotonic solution—a solution with the same amount of salts and minerals as the original sample). This will give a 1/10 dilution. Since dilutions are traditionally indicated using scientific notation, this would be considered a 10-1 dilution. Taking 1 mL of this 1/10 dilution and mixing it with 9 mL of diluent will then give a 1/100, or 10-2 dilution. Additional dilutions may be made in this fashion. These dilutions are then spread onto a series of plates containing a growth medium such as nutrient agar (Figure 1), and the number of colonies that grow is then counted as a way of estimating the number of in the original sample.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Diagram of a serial dilution: 1 mL of sample is transferred to a tube labeled 10^-1, 1 mL of the 10^-1 tube is transferred to a tube labeled 10^-2, and so on until a tube has been produced with a dilution of 10^-6. 0.1 mL of the contents of each tube is then transferred to Petri dish.

pageData.text: To calculate the total number of <button class=glossary-text>CFU</button> in a sample, use the following formula.

pageData.altText: Equation 1: Number of CFU over Volume plated (in mL) x Dilution factor = CFU/mL

pageData.text: For example, suppose you count 35 colonies (representing 35 CFU) on an agar plate made with 0.1 mL of a 10<sup>-3</sup> dilution of the original sample. The number of CFU, 35, is divided by the volume of 0.1 mL. This is multiplied by the dilution factor. The dilution of 10<sup>-3</sup> means 1/1,000, thus, a dilution factor of 1,000. Note that the CFU/mL should be in scientific notation.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: 35 CFU over 0.1 mL x 1,000 = 350,000 or 3.5 x 10 to the 5th power CFU/mL

pageData.text: E. coli, the bacterium used in this investigation, is a rapidly growing microbe that resides in the intestines of humans and other animals and is commonly used as an indicator of fecal contamination. Bacteria typically grow by a process known as . This means that one cell splits in two, which then split in four, which split in eight, and so on. This is called . Under optimal conditions, E. coli can divide itself and double its population size every 20 minutes. Thus, E. coli is a favored species for the study of bacterial populations.

In this investigation an indirect <button class=glossary-text>turbidity</button> method will be used to visualize the effect of <button class=glossary-text>serial dilution</button> on bacterial population density and to observe changes in turbidity as the population of each dilution tube expands over time. A <button class=glossary-text>standard plate count</button> will be used to determine the number of CFU in an original sample.

pageData.question: Which of the following best explains why E. coli is often used to study bacterial populations?

options.text: E. coli is an indicator of fecal contamination.
E. coli is found in humans and other animals.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Under optimal conditions, E. coli can divide itself and double its population size every 20 minutes. Thus, E. coli is a favored species for the study of bacterial populations.

pageData.question: In this investigation, what method will be used to visualize the effect of serial dilution?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: In this investigation an indirect turbidity method will be used to visualize the effect of serial dilution on bacterial population density and to observe changes in turbidity as the population of each dilution tube expands over time.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Because it is impossible to count each individual colony on a plate with confluent growth, it is therefore standard practice to perform a serial dilution of the original sample. To do this, 1 mL of the original sample is mixed with 9 mL of diluent (either sterile water or an isotonic solution—a solution with the same amount of salts and minerals as the original sample). This will give a 1/10 dilution. Since dilutions are traditionally indicated using scientific notation, this would be considered a 10-1 dilution. Taking 1 mL of this 1/10 dilution and mixing it with 9 mL of diluent will then give a 1/100, or 10-2 dilution. Additional dilutions may be made in this fashion. These dilutions are then spread onto a series of plates containing a growth medium such as nutrient agar, and the number of colonies that grow is then counted as a way of estimating the number of CFU in the original sample.E. coli, the bacterium used in this investigation, is a rapidly growing microbe that resides in the intestines of humans and other animals and is commonly used as an indicator of fecal contamination. Bacteria typically grow by a process known as binary fission. This means that one cell splits in two, which then split in four, which split in eight, and so on. This is called exponential growth. Inn this investigation, a standard plate count will be used to determine the number of CFU in an original sample.

pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow of this investigation. Before beginning, disinfect your work surface, prepare your disposal jar and prepare your cultures. Then, cover the work surface in disinfectant-soaked paper towels. In activity 1, label your tubes. Then, create a serial dilution of the E. coli culture in 6 broth tubes. In activity 2, label the plates and transfer broth from the tube to the appropriate plate. Then, spread the liquid evenly over the plate. After you have inoculated 6 plates, assess the turbidity of the tubes. Then, incubate the broth and plates. After 24 and 48 hours of incubation, record the turbidity of the broth tubes and count the plate colonies. If the colony count is less than 30, record it as TFTC, or too few to count. If the count is greater than 300, record it as TNTC, or too numerous to count. If the count is 30-300, record the number of colonies. Then, determine the CFU per milliliter value for each countable plate and the average CFU per milliliter using countable plates.

pageData.text: Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) as described in the Safety and Procedure sections.
Refer to your instructions and video on safe practices in the microbiology laboratory before beginning this investigation.
Isopropyl alcohol is flammable. Keep containers of isopropyl alcohol away from any heat or flame sources.
pageData.altText: flammable symbol

pageData.text: Chlorine bleach is a corrosive material. Use these materials near a source of running water that can be used as a safety eyewash or safety shower if any corrosive material comes in contact with skin or eyes. Do not use bleach in an area without proper ventilation, such as an open window or a bathroom with a fan.
pageData.altText: corrosion symbol

pageData.text: Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity.

Disinfect the work area with a 10% bleach solution (one part bleach to nine parts tap water) before starting the investigation. After completing your work, disinfect and discard any used inoculating tools and unneeded cultures. Disinfect the work area with a 10% bleach solution followed by soap and water. Always wear PPE while disinfecting.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

typeBefore.text: Note: Use correct aseptic technique as you are working through this investigation. You may wish to review the Aseptic Technique and Use of Media investigation to refresh your memory. In particular, each time you remove the cap from a tube, the cap should be held, not placed on the work surface. The open mouth of each glass culture tube should be flamed as soon as the cap is removed and immediately before the cap is replaced. When opening a Petri dish (agar plate) to add inoculum (the source of living microorganisms), do not remove the lid completely. Instead, open it slightly, insert your inoculating tool, and then close the lid immediately following the inoculation procedure. In this manner, the lid of a Petri dish serves as a shield to keep out dust and other contaminants.

Culture Recommendations:You will need a relatively fresh broth culture of E. coli in order for this investigation to be successful.
  • If you have a broth culture that is no more than two weeks old, you may skip Preparation Steps 5–11.
  • If you need to reactivate a lyophilized culture, follow the directions that came with the cultures using proper aseptic technique. You may wish to first review the following video:

E. coli will grow at room temperature; however, it will grow faster around 37° C (99° F). Once growth is apparent in the tryptic soy broth, you may skip Preparation Steps 5–11.
  • If you have a broth culture that is more than two weeks old, carry out all of the Preparation steps before proceeding to the Activity.
Follow your instructor’s directions on whether to keep or discard your E. coli culture at the end of this investigation.

pageData.text: Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and warm water. Dry your hands, then put on your PPE.
Disinfect the work surface, culture tube rack, and grease pencil or permanent marker with a 10% bleach solution.
Prepare your disposal jar by filling it with 70% isopropyl alcohol.
Obtain the liquid paraffin candle from the equipment set. Light the candle. Be sure to keep the candle a safe distance from the open container of isopropyl alcohol.

pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol
pageData.text: Retrieve the needed media and, if applicable, lyophilized culture, from storage. If the media have been stored in the refrigerator, allow them to sit for approximately 15 minutes to warm up to room temperature.

Mix the contents of the reactivated or older E. coli culture by tapping the tube or rolling it between your palms. Aseptically transfer a loop of broth to a fresh tube of room temperature nutrient broth labeled “E. coli.”

pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol
pageData.text: Place the loop in the disposal jar; let it sit for at least 30 minutes, then discard the loop in the garbage.
Extinguish the candle, and empty the alcohol from the disposal jar as described in Disposal and Cleanup. Keep the disposal jar for later use.
Incubate the inoculated broth tube upright in the rack with the cap slightly loose. E. coli will grow at room temperature; however, it will grow faster around 37° C (99° F).
Disinfect the work area with a 10% bleach solution, remove your PPE, and wash your hands thoroughly.

pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol
pageData.text: Allow between 2 and 4 days of incubation for the broth to become turbid (cloudy), indicating that growth is occurring. Do not proceed until the culture is growing well.
Prepare to work as described in Steps 1–4.

Obtain all materials needed from the equipment set and culture materials, as well as those needed but not supplied. Any media stored in the refrigerator should be allowed to sit at room temperature for about 15 minutes prior to use.

Use of Serological PipettesIn this investigation, you will use sterile glass serological pipettes to measure liquid volumes. The “secret” to success is to take your time and use the amount of pressure applied to the pipette bulb to control the amount and speed of pipetting.Before you begin, view the following videos:

• Begin by unwrapping the top of the pipette but leaving the rest in its sterile packaging.
  • Attach the bulb firmly to the top of the pipette, but don’t slide it down past the double lines that surround the cotton plug. Leave the rest of the pipette in its packaging until ready to use.
  • Slide the pipette out of its packaging. Notice the volume markings on the sides of the pipette. One side has a scale with small numbers ranging from 1.0 mL at the top to 0.1 mL near the tip. Use this scale in the investigation, because it is designed to measure the amount of liquid drawn into the pipette. (The scale on the other side, with larger numbers, is reversed, because it is used to measure the amount of liquid dispensed from the pipette.)
  • Partially depress the bulb and immerse the tip of the pipette into the liquid to be transferred. Gradually release pressure on the bulb, and allow the liquid to be slowly drawn into the pipette. Do not draw too much liquid into the pipette. Even with the protective sterile cotton plug in place, it is possible to exert too much suction and draw liquid into the bulb.
  • Position the pipette in the container that will receive the liquid, then slowly depress the bulb, and dispense the contents of the pipette.

Cover the work area with two or three layers of paper towels, and saturate them with surface disinfectant. The pipetting procedure you will use for Activities 1 and 2 often result in dripping of bacterial cultures. The paper towels will catch any drips, and the surface disinfectant will kill most bacteria.

In Activity 1, you will perform a of your E. coli culture by transferring liquid from the culture to a fresh broth tube, mixing the contents, then transferring liquid from the broth tube to a new tube.

Using the grease pencil or permanent marker, label the six nutrient broth tubes as follows:
10-1, 10-2, 10-3, 10-4, 10-5, and 10-6.

In the background, a <button class=glossary-text>serial dilution</button> was explained as adding 1 mL of sample to 9 mL of <button class=glossary-text>diluent</button> (the liquid used to dilute the sample). Since the nutrient broth tubes already contain 10 mL each (a standard volume for commercially available prepared broth), it is necessary to remove 1 mL of broth before adding 1 mL of sample.

Use a serological pipette to aseptically remove exactly 1 mL of broth from each of the six nutrient broth tubes. Use the same pipette to remove the broth from each tube. The broth is sterile, and therefore may be disposed of down a drain along with running water. When you are finished, remove the bulb from the pipette, and place the pipette in the disposal jar.

Take the E. coli broth culture and, with its cap tightly closed, tap or roll the tube between your palms to mix the contents. From this point on, the original culture will be referred to as the sample.
Use a new serological pipette to aseptically withdraw exactly 1 mL of the sample and transfer it to the nutrient broth tube labeled 10<sup>-1</sup>. Place the used pipette in the disposal jar.

Mix the contents of the 10<sup>-1</sup> tube. Using a new serological pipette, aseptically transfer 1 mL from the 10<sup>-1</sup> tube to the 10<sup>-2</sup> tube. Place the used pipette in the disposal jar. Repeat this process in order to inoculate the 10<sup>-3</sup>, 10<sup>-4</sup>, 10<sup>-5</sup>, and 10<sup>-6</sup> tubes, as shown in <button class=resource-text>Figure 1</button>. Use a new serological pipette for each transfer.

In Activity 2, you will transfer liquid from your tubes to nutrient agar plates and incubate them over 48 hours. You will then perform a to determine the number of colonies on the plate and use this to determine the /mL and average CFU/mL for all . You will also measure the of the broth tubes over the same interval.

pages.title:
A
 Inoculation of Agar Plates from a Serial Dilution (6 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
 Inoculation of Agar Plates from a Serial Dilution (6 steps)

typeBefore.text: Before starting Activity 2, please watch the following videos

pageData.text:
Label the six tryptic soy agar plates as follows:
10-1, 10-2, 10-3, 10-4, 10-5, and 10-6.

Mix the 10-1 broth by tapping or rolling the tube, and use a serological pipette to aseptically transfer 0.1 mL of broth to the surface of the agar in the plate labeled “10-1”as shown in . Place the used pipette in the disposal jar.

Take a single, sterile plastic cell spreader from its pack, and use it to distribute the 0.1 mL of 10<sup>-1</sup> broth evenly across the surface of the agar in the 10<sup>-1</sup> plate. To do this, gently place the spreader on the plate in such a way that the side with the handle is in the center of the plate while the end of the spreader is touching the rim of the plate. Without pushing down, slowly rotate the plate. This will distribute the broth evenly over the surface of the agar. When finished, place the used spreader in the disposal jar.
Repeat Steps 2 and 3 with the remaining broth dilutions and agar plates as shown in Figure 1. Use a new pipette and a new cell spreader for each dilution.
Invert the plates (turn them upside-down) and set them aside for incubation.

You will also incubate the sample and the broth dilution tubes. First, however, assess their and record your data in Data Table 1. For incubation, loosen the cap of each tube very slightly—about one quarter of a turn back from finger-tightness.
Let the cultures incubate with tube caps slightly loose and plates inverted, for 24 hours.

After 24 hours, take a picture of the tubes arranged in the culture tube rack with their dilution labels visible. Then take pictures of each plate. For photos of microbial cultures, avoid use of the flash, which will simply be reflected off the glass or plastic culture container. You may need to experiment with lighting conditions and camera angles to get the best pictures in your workspace. Do not take the lids off the Petri dishes or caps off the tubes for photos. Record your data in Data Tables 1 and 2.
After another 24 hours of incubation (48 total), take another set of pictures and record your data in Data Tables 1 and 2.
Use the counts from Data Table 2 to determine the CFU/mL in the original sample.

Estimations of Turbidity in Broth
For the most accurate results, assess in a place with good lighting. With the cap tightened, tap or swirl the broth tube or roll it in your hands to mix the contents. Hold the turbidity reference marker behind the tube and look through the tube at the reference. Compare what you see with the turbidity scale to estimate the turbidity of the broth in the tube. View the video on Assessing Turbidity for guidance. Record your turbidity estimates in Data Table 1.

Standard Plate Count
Count the number of colonies on the surface of the agar in each Petri dish. Use the grease pencil to mark individual colonies as you count them, so you do not count the same twice. Record your counts in Data Table 2. If you count over 300 colonies, stop counting and just note “TNTC” (too numerous to count) for that plate. If growth prevents the counting of individual colonies, note “TNTC” for that plate as well.

Determination of CFU/mL in Original Sample
In order to estimate population size from a , the ideal number of colonies on a single agar plate will be between 30 and 300. A plate with this number of colonies is said to be a . You will use only CFU from countable plates to calculate CFU/mL. If there are fewer than 30 colonies on a plate, then that plate is “TFTC”(too few to count); do not use it to calculate CFU/mL. If the growth on a plate is confluent, or if you count 300 colonies and there are still colonies remaining, that plate is considered “TNTC” and should not be used in calculating CFU/mL.

Note: When recording your colony counts in Data Table 2, you probably did not notice a difference in the number of colonies between 24 and 48 hours of incubation. However, if you do see more colonies at 48 hours, that could mean you overlooked very small colonies during the first count. You may then use the data from the longer time interval to calculate CFU/mL. On the other hand, some colonies may grow so much between 24 and 48 hours that you have confluent growth at 48 hours. In this case, use the shorter time period to calculate CFU/mL.

Select your countable plates from Data Table 2, and enter the information in Data Table 3. You will probably not have six countable plates. That is normal; just leave any extra rows blank. Use to calculate the CFU/mL for each countable plate. If you have multiple countable plates, then add all their CFU/mL, and divide by the total number of countable plates to determine the average CFU/mL.

To dispose of used inoculating loops, cell spreaders, and pipettes, let them soak in the disposal jar with isopropyl alcohol for at least 30 minutes; then, while wearing PPE, pour the alcohol down the drain with the faucet running. Allow the faucet to run for at least 30 seconds to dilute the alcohol. Wrap the loops, spreaders, and pipettes in an opaque plastic bag and put them in the garbage.
Keep your original broth culture of E. coli unless otherwise directed by your instructor.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: To dispose of cultures that are no longer needed, put on your PPE, ensure adequate ventilation, and fill a lidded plastic container large enough to hold all the cultures with a 10% bleach solution. While holding each tube or plate submerged in the bleach solution, open the tube or plate. Allow the cultures to soak in the bleach for at least 24 hours.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Then, while wearing your PPE, pour the bleach down the drain with the faucet running. Let the faucet continue to run for at least 30 seconds to dilute the bleach. Place the disinfected tubes in an opaque plastic bag, and discard in the garbage.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

text: After working with microbes, disinfect the work space with a 10% bleach solution, and then clean with soap and water. Always wear PPE while disinfecting.

pageData.text: You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.

text: How did your turbidity estimates of the serial dilution tubes at the start of this investigation relate to the final results of your standard plate count?
Describe what happened as you observed the broth tubes from your serial dilution over time. Did you observe any evidence of bacterial growth during the incubation period?

Which would be more accurate in terms of determining numbers of viable bacterial cells in a population: an estimation of turbidity in broth, or a standard plate count? Why? Discuss sources of inaccuracy in both approaches.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Diagram of a serial dilution: 1 mL of sample is transferred to a tube labeled 10^-1, 1 mL of the 10^-1 tube is transferred to a tube labeled 10^-2, and so on until a tube has been produced with a dilution of 10^-6. 0.1 mL of the contents of each tube is then transferred to Petri dish.
pageData.content: Figure 1. Diagram of a serial dilution

pageData.altText: Equation 1: Number of CFU over Volume plated (in mL) x Dilution factor = CFU/mL

A map describing the procedural workflow of this investigation. Before beginning, disinfect your work surface, prepare your disposal jar and prepare your cultures. Then, cover the work surface in disinfectant-soaked paper towels. In activity 1, label your tubes. Then, create a serial dilution of the E. coli culture in 6 broth tubes. In activity 2, label the plates and transfer broth from the tube to the appropriate plate. Then, spread the liquid evenly over the plate. After you have inoculated 6 plates, assess the turbidity of the tubes. Then, incubate the broth and plates. After 24 and 48 hours of incubation, record the turbidity of the broth tubes and count the plate colonies. If the colony count is less than 30, record it as TFTC, or too few to count. If the count is greater than 300, record it as TNTC, or too numerous to count. If the count is 30-300, record the number of colonies. Then, determine the CFU per milliliter value for each countable plate and the average CFU per milliliter using countable plates.

How to Inoculate an Agar Plate Using a Cell Spreader

data.title: Binary fission
data.content: The reproduction of a cell by division into two approximately equal parts

data.title: Colony
data.content: An aggregation of cells descended from either a single cell or a small number of closely-adhering cells

data.title: Colony-forming unit (CFU)
data.content: A unit used to estimate the number of viable microbial cells in a sample

data.title: Confluent
data.content: Describes microbial growth that is continuous and thick such that individual colonies cannot be discerned

data.title: Countable plate
data.content: An inoculated agar plate with a standard plate count of between 30 and 300 CFU

data.title: Exponential growth
data.content: A growth rate that becomes more rapid in proportion to the growing total number or size

data.title: Serial dilution
data.content: A series of dilutions that will reduce the concentration of a substance to a more usable concentration

data.title: Standard plate count
data.content: A direct-counting method that quantifies the number of colonies as a representation of the number of viable microbial cells on an agar plate

data.title: Turbidity
data.content: Cloudiness in a solution that is a result of small particles in suspension
